questions.question: What has nature provided us with?
options: b) A number of natural resources
questions.correct_answer: b) A number of natural resources
questions.explanation: Nature has provided us with a number of natural resources.

questions.question: What is the most important crisis caused by disturbing natural cycles?
questions.correct_answer: b) Water crisis
questions.explanation: Due to excessive use of resources, we are facing ecological imbalance which disturbs the natural cycles. The most important one is water crisis.

questions.question: What percentage of the earth's surface is covered by land?
questions.explanation: Land forms about 20% of the earth's surface.

questions.question: What percentage of land is covered by deserts and tundras?
questions.explanation: Out of the 20% land, 21.2% is covered by deserts and tundras.

questions.question: What percentage of land is occupied by forests, woodlands and grasslands?
questions.explanation: About 41.6% of land is occupied by forests, woodlands and grasslands.

questions.question: What percentage of land is fit for cultivation?
questions.explanation: So only 13.4% of land is fit for cultivation.

questions.question: What is the surface layer of the earth called?
questions.correct_answer: b) Soil
questions.explanation: The surface layer of the earth is called soil. About four-fifth of the land consists of soil.

questions.question: Land or soil can be damaged by which two types of activities?
questions.correct_answer: b) Industrial and agricultural
questions.explanation: Land or soil can be damaged by industrial activities and agricultural activities.

questions.question: Which industrial activities can cause soil pollution on a massive scale?
options: b) Mining of coal, metal processing, disposal of wastes, fly ash from thermal power stations
questions.correct_answer: b) Mining of coal, metal processing, disposal of wastes, fly ash from thermal power stations
questions.explanation: Mining of coal and other minerals, metal processing, disposal of soil wastes, domestic wastes and industrial wastes like fly ash from thermal power stations can cause soil pollution on a massive scale.

questions.question: When natural vegetation is removed, what else is lost besides the nutrients stored in vegetation?
options: b) The organic matter and nutrients accumulated in the soil
questions.correct_answer: b) The organic matter and nutrients accumulated in the soil
questions.explanation: When natural vegetation is removed, not only are the nutrients stored in vegetation removed, but the organic matter and nutrients accumulated in the soil are also lost.

questions.question: What agricultural activities lead to soil pollution?
options: b) Overuse of fertilisers, insecticides, herbicides and pesticides
questions.correct_answer: b) Overuse of fertilisers, insecticides, herbicides and pesticides
questions.explanation: The agricultural activities which can lead to soil pollution are overuse of fertilisers, insecticides, herbicides and pesticides.

questions.question: What is the effect called when overuse of chemicals adversely changes the properties of soil making it infertile?
questions.correct_answer: b) Residual effect
questions.explanation: Overuse of these chemicals can adversely change the properties of soil. This is called residual effect which makes the soil infertile for cultivation.

questions.question: What also leads to the loss of soil fertility besides the residual effect?
options: b) Water logging and application of non-biodegradable chemicals
questions.correct_answer: b) Water logging and application of non-biodegradable chemicals
questions.explanation: Water logging and application of non-biodegradable chemicals also lead to the loss of soil fertility.

questions.question: Water is needed for many purposes. Which of the following is NOT mentioned?
questions.correct_answer: c) Flying
questions.explanation: Water is needed by us for many purposes like drinking, washing, irrigation, transport, industrial use, etc.

questions.question: How is the distribution of fresh water?
questions.correct_answer: b) Geographically uneven, varying greatly
questions.explanation: The distribution of fresh water is geographically uneven, varying greatly from country to country and even within a country from one region to another.

questions.question: What does domestic waste include?
options: b) Waste water from bathing and washing containing oils, detergents and bleaching chemicals
questions.correct_answer: b) Waste water from bathing and washing containing oils, detergents and bleaching chemicals
questions.explanation: Domestic waste includes waste water from bathing and washing. It contains oils, detergents and bleaching chemicals, etc.

questions.question: What disease can spread when domestic waste contaminates water?
questions.correct_answer: b) Cholera
questions.explanation: Domestic waste contaminates the water, making it unfit for human consumption, besides spreading diseases like cholera, etc.

questions.question: What may industrial waste effluents contain?
options: b) Tardy, foul smelling and poisonous oil products, acids, alkalis
questions.correct_answer: b) Tardy, foul smelling and poisonous oil products, acids, alkalis
questions.explanation: Industrial waste effluents may contain tardy, foul smelling and poisonous oil products, acids, alkalis, etc.

questions.question: What happens to pesticides sprayed on crops?
options: b) They get washed away by rain water and ultimately pollute waterbodies
c) They stay on crops forever
questions.correct_answer: b) They get washed away by rain water and ultimately pollute waterbodies
questions.explanation: Pesticides sprayed on crops also get washed away by rain water. These chemicals ultimately find their way into waterbodies and pollute the water.

questions.question: What diseases do wastes in water cause in human beings?
questions.correct_answer: b) Diarrhoea and gastroenteritis
questions.explanation: These wastes adversely affect the aquatic animals and plants and cause diseases like diarrhoea and gastroenteritis in human beings.

questions.question: What happens during mining when it rains?
options: b) Loose ore is washed down into rivers and lakes polluting water
questions.correct_answer: b) Loose ore is washed down into rivers and lakes polluting water
questions.explanation: Wherever mining of metals is practised during rains, a considerable quantity of the loose ore is washed down into rivers, lakes and other bodies of standing water.

questions.question: What is eutrophication?
options: b) Luxuriant growth of algae due to nutrients from sewage in waterbodies
questions.correct_answer: b) Luxuriant growth of algae due to nutrients from sewage in waterbodies
questions.explanation: Addition of sewage water makes lakes, ponds and other waterbodies very rich in nutrients. This results in luxuriant growth of algae. This phenomenon is called eutrophication.

questions.question: What does the decomposition of algae in eutrophication deplete?
questions.correct_answer: b) Oxygen supply in water
questions.explanation: The decomposition of algae depletes oxygen supply in water. They also produce toxic substances which are harmful to the aquatic animals.

questions.question: What is the best method to control eutrophication?
options: b) Treating waste water before discharging it into waterbodies
questions.correct_answer: b) Treating waste water before discharging it into waterbodies
questions.explanation: The best method to control eutrophication is to treat waste water before discharging it into waterbodies.

questions.question: What does radioactive waste from nuclear installations cause?
questions.correct_answer: b) Radioactive pollution
questions.explanation: When radioactive waste from nuclear installations are discharged into water, they also cause radioactive pollution.

questions.question: What is thermal pollution of water?
options: b) When hot water from cooling plants raises the temperature of waterbodies
questions.correct_answer: b) When hot water from cooling plants raises the temperature of waterbodies
questions.explanation: When hot water from cooling plants of industries, nuclear reactors and power generating plants are released directly into waterbodies, it raises the temperature of the waterbodies. This is termed as thermal pollution.

questions.question: What are the main air pollutants?
options: b) Carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and unburnt particles
questions.correct_answer: b) Carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and unburnt particles
questions.explanation: The main air pollutants are carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and other unburnt particles.

questions.question: What respiratory diseases do humans and animals suffer from due to air pollution?
options: b) Asthma, pneumonia, bronchitis, and other lung diseases
questions.correct_answer: b) Asthma, pneumonia, bronchitis, and other lung diseases
questions.explanation: Due to air pollution, human beings and other animals suffer from respiratory diseases like asthma, pneumonia, bronchitis, and other lung diseases.

questions.question: What results from the increase in percentage of sulphur dioxide and nitrous oxides in atmosphere?
questions.correct_answer: b) Acid rain
questions.explanation: Increase in the percentage of sulphur dioxide and nitrous oxides in atmosphere increases the deposition of acids in rain water and results in acid rain.

questions.question: What is smog?
options: b) Combination of smoke and fog
questions.correct_answer: b) Combination of smoke and fog
questions.explanation: Gases and unburnt carbon particles released by vehicles may combine with fog (especially in winter season) and produce smog (smoke + fog).

questions.question: Which chemicals used for refrigeration can attack the ozone layer?
questions.correct_answer: b) Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)
questions.explanation: A number of air pollutants can attack the ozone layer. Major among these are chemicals such as chlorofluorocarbons used for refrigeration.

questions.question: What does the ozone layer in the atmosphere prevent?
options: b) Harmful ultraviolet rays of the Sun from reaching the earth
questions.correct_answer: b) Harmful ultraviolet rays of the Sun from reaching the earth
questions.explanation: Ozone forms a protective layer in the atmosphere which prevents the harmful ultraviolet rays of the Sun from reaching the earth.

questions.question: What disease can be caused when organisms are exposed to harmful ultraviolet rays due to damaged ozone layer?
questions.correct_answer: b) Skin cancer
questions.explanation: When the ozone layer is damaged organisms are exposed to the harmful ultraviolet rays which can cause diseases such as skin cancer.

questions.question: What fraction of the earth's total land area is covered by forests?
questions.correct_answer: b) One third
questions.explanation: Approximately one third of the earth's total land area is covered by forests.

questions.question: Forests are storehouses of:
questions.correct_answer: b) Biodiversity
questions.explanation: Forests are valuable wealth of a country. We get many useful products from forests. They are storehouses of biodiversity.

questions.question: Why are more and more trees being cut down?
options: b) To meet the ever increasing demand of wood and timber, for roads, railways and industries
questions.correct_answer: b) To meet the ever increasing demand of wood and timber, for roads, railways and industries
questions.explanation: More and more trees are being cut down to meet the ever increasing demand of wood and timber. Construction of roads, railway lines, and installation of new industries also prompt man to cut forests.

questions.question: What does deforestation result in?
options: b) Soil erosion and decreased soil fertility
questions.correct_answer: b) Soil erosion and decreased soil fertility
questions.explanation: Deforestation results in soil erosion and decreased soil fertility.

questions.question: In drier areas, what can deforestation lead to?
questions.correct_answer: b) Desertification
questions.explanation: In drier areas, deforestation can lead to desertification.

questions.question: What happens to the amount of running water when forests are cleared?
options: b) Increases several fold causing frequent floods
questions.correct_answer: b) Increases several fold causing frequent floods
questions.explanation: When the forest is cleared, the amount of running water flowing into rivers and streams increases several fold causing frequent floods.

questions.question: What does deforestation cause to forest dwelling plants, animals and microbial species?
options: b) Extinction and loss of irreplaceable genetic resources
questions.correct_answer: b) Extinction and loss of irreplaceable genetic resources
questions.explanation: Deforestation causes the extinction of forest dwelling plants, animals and microbial species resulting in a loss of irreplaceable genetic resources.

questions.question: What does burning of fossil fuels lead to?
questions.correct_answer: b) Air pollution
questions.explanation: Burning of fossil fuels leads to air pollution.

questions.question: What does land excavation during coal mining lead to?
questions.correct_answer: b) Erosion of soil
questions.explanation: During coal mining, land excavation leads to erosion of soil.

questions.question: What can radioactive sources of energy cause if necessary precautions are not taken?
options: b) Genetic defects in man and animals
questions.correct_answer: b) Genetic defects in man and animals
questions.explanation: Radioactive sources of energy can cause genetic defects in man and animals if the necessary precautions against exposure to these are not taken.

questions.question: What type of resources are minerals?
questions.correct_answer: b) Exhaustible, non-renewable resources
questions.explanation: Minerals are exhaustible, non-renewable resources found in the earth's crust.

questions.question: What is happening to mineral resources due to rapid expansion of industries?
options: b) Getting depleted at a rapid pace
questions.correct_answer: b) Getting depleted at a rapid pace
questions.explanation: Due to rapid expansion of industries, the consumption of minerals has increased tremendously all over the world. Thus these resources are getting depleted at a rapid pace.

questions.question: What have oceans received during the past 50 years?
options: b) A wide variety of harmful pollutants
questions.correct_answer: b) A wide variety of harmful pollutants
questions.explanation: During the past 50 years, the oceans have received a wide variety of harmful pollutants.

questions.question: Where is the city of Minamata located?
options: b) Japan (west coast of Southern Kyushu)
questions.correct_answer: b) Japan (west coast of Southern Kyushu)
questions.explanation: The city of Minamata is located on the west coast of Southern Kyushu, Japan.

questions.question: What is Minamata city best known as?
options: b) Former site of an environmental disaster caused by mercury pollution
questions.correct_answer: b) Former site of an environmental disaster caused by mercury pollution
questions.explanation: The city of Minamata is best known as the former site of an environmental disaster caused by industrial pollution of the Minamata Bay with mercury.

questions.question: What did medical researchers identify as the cause of the Minamata disease in 1956?
options: b) Heavy-metal poisoning caused by eating fish and shellfish from contaminated bay
questions.correct_answer: b) Heavy-metal poisoning caused by eating fish and shellfish from contaminated bay
questions.explanation: By the end of 1956, medical researchers identified the disease as heavy-metal poisoning caused by eating the fish and shellfish of Minamata Bay.

questions.question: In 1963, Public Health Services researchers traced the Minamata disease to which substance from Chisso?
questions.correct_answer: b) Mercury
questions.explanation: In 1963, Public Health Services researchers traced the disease to mercury from Chisso.
